  27. I hated painting my nails, because even hours after painting, I would smudge and ruin my nails. When someone suggested Seche Vite, I snatched it up. The reviews were great, and it was a good price.<br /><br />Although it's supposed to \\"dry fast\\" I don't feel that it does. I'm not sure if I'm using too much or too little, but even an hour later I'll sometimes dent the nail on accident. I don't have many coats below (three at MOST, and only with a thin polish) so I'm unsure of why I'm not getting the same dry time. That said, it dries MUCH faster than anything I've ever tried, and continue to use it.<br /><br />My BIGGEST COMPLAINT about this product is that you only get to use about half of the bottle. It's great and convenient until halfway down. I have to tilt the polish all over to try and get it on the brush, and even then it doesn't work well. That's very annoying.<br /><br />I don't have problems with shrinkage, but sometimes my nails will chip at the base a day or two later. I know many enjoy the \\"glossy\\" look, but I prefer more matte nails. I will be a happy girl when there's a fast-dry top coat that doesn't have extra shine.

  54. If you're wondering why this is so cheap it's because the product is counterfeit. I noticed immediately that the box didn't look as right. When I smelled the polish itself, it had a too strong odor that most fake polishes have. The bottle was misprinted and looked cheaply made. Also, the bottle itself was semi dirty and from experience, I know that that's not how real Seche Vite bottles are. On the plus side, it came with free \\"OPI\\" slippers which was a nice surprise.
  55. Don't get me wrong this topcoat is okay. But I have to say I've had much better results with the Sally Hansen topcoats. When I saw the massive number of 5 star reviews for Seche, I ordered a bottle expecting it to be at least as good as the Sally Hansen topcoat. I was really surprised to find that my nail polish chips a LOT sooner using this topcoat then when using my previous stuff. I didn't even realize just how well my last topcoat was working until I used this instead. When I use any of the Sally Hansen topcoats, I can work my nails hard for 5 days (typing all day at work, doing dishes, taking care of my kids, etc) and I won't get my first chip till about 5 days in. I've painted my nails twice now, using this topcoat afterwards, and by day 3 my nails are chipping all over.<br /><br />I like how fast this topcoat dries, but it doesn't seem to prevent chips as well as the Sally Hansen brand topcoat does. I'll use the rest of the bottle as my a topcoat on my toenail polish, since they never seem to chip anyway. But for my fingernails I'll use something else, since with this I end up having to redo my nails more frequently than before. But I'm glad I tried it out, to see how well it would work.

  61. This is my 4th bottle of Seche Vite and I'll continue to purchase this top coat because it's life.
  62. Before I talk about the product itself, I feel that it is important to mention the over-exaggerated topic of toluene. Whenever a \\"health scare\\" like this comes up, I always do the research. After reading so many reviews complaining about this horrible ingredient, I thought to myself, \\"If it's so bad, then why are the FDA allowing it into products at all?\\" Sure, many brands have removed the ingredient, but if it were truly unsafe to use for the purpose for which it was intended, it wouldn't be allowed in any brand. So after having done some research from reliable, credible sources, I stumbled across a few facts.<br /><br />First of all, toluene is not cancer causing - so no need to worry about that. Over exposure to the ingredient can cause heart and neurological damage. For this reason alone, a warning label HAS to go on the box. It's the same with paint thinners, gasoline, lacquers, and other industrial products made with the ingredient (or any known harmful ingredient) that the warnings be printed on the product. Please be aware that serious side effects are the result of OVER EXPOSURE and that regular, intended usage is nothing at all to be concerned about. The quantity of the ingredient is so low, the only way you'd really do damage is if you sat there and huffed the bottle. Using it for the purpose of a nail polish top coat is completely safe.<br /><br />I wouldn't necessarily recommend using this if you are pregnant. All of the evidence points to severe effects only occurring with excessive exposure, but this is the only time I personally might not take the risk simply because it is strong-smelling. But overall, use this product as you are supposed to and you'll have nothing to worry about. Remember to look at factual sources of evidence, and not automatically assume that someone's anecdotal \\"knowledge\\" is somehow more accurate. You don't even have to take my word for it; the sources are out there for you to research.<br /><br />The product itself, as most others have mentioned, is fantastic. Dries within seconds and it's such a relief not to feel like I can't touch anything for several hours! This is the first bottle I've used, but so far it is my HG of top coats. My nails are hard, dry, and don't chip with this stuff on. In fact, it's somewhat hard to take the polish off when you're ready! I cannot find a single thing wrong with this product and will continue to buy it for as long as it's made.ers have mentioned, is fantastic. Dries within seconds and it's such a relief not to feel like I can't touch anything for several hours! This is the first bottle I've used, but so far it is my HG of top coats. My nails are hard, dry, and don't chip with this stuff on. In fact, it's somewhat hard to take the polish off when you're ready! I cannot find a single thing wrong with this product and will continue to buy it for as long as it's made.

  64. I change my polish often so I can appreciate a fast drying top coat. This fries within 2 mins and the glossy finish it has is wonderful!
  65. Good stuff but can buy locally. Don't waste money on shipping
  66. This top coat is really amazing except, it is just a little too thick for me as a top coat.

  77. Seche Vite is my go to top coat.<br /><br />What's there to say? It's quick drying, crystal clear, and it gives you a wonderful glossy finish. It's a life saver for those times I paint my nails in a rush before leaving the house, or nights when I have the bright idea of painting my nails right before bed. No more sheet marks!<br /><br />It's my favorite top coat for protecting nail art, as I find it doesn't smudge or smear my designs. And it is great for sealing in unruly glitter!<br /><br />The only downside to this top coat is that it does suffer some shrinkage, which becomes more apparent the longer you wear it. You'll start to see your nail color has begun to pull back from the nail, and it may even curl up. I'm the kind of girl who paints her nails at least three times a week, so I rarely wear a manicure long enough for this to become an issue. However, I know many view it as a serious product fault so it's something to be aware of.

  150. I originally tried this product based solely on its description on another website. The idea that it penetrates all layers of polish to make one, solid covering sounded intriguing. Add to that the \\"self-leveling\\" properties and quick-dry claims and I was sold. Fast forward to when I finally got around to purchasing it. The first time I topped off my carefully executed manicure with this delectable treat, I knew I would never use another top coat ever again. It brushed on so smoothly, leveling everything off beautifully. As I continued to use this product over the course of dozens of manicures and pedicures, I grew to love it more and more. It would even out creases caused by my carelessness and still leave me with a glass-like finish that dried lickety-split. Now, one thing I MUST point out is that, over time, this product will begin to thicken due to evaporation. It is IMPERATIVE that you DO NOT attempt to thin it out with acetone or nail polish remover. Seche has been able to pin-point the cause of this thickening and they created [[ASIN:B0017ZDH52 Seche Restore Restoration Thinner .5 fl oz (14 ml)]] to reverse the evaporation. Seche Restore is specifically formulated to replace only those ingredients that have evaporated, restoring the once thick mess back to its former glory. So, be sure to tightly cap it after every use, and be prepared for it to thicken up. It will happen. It happens to ALL nail polishes and top coats. This one is no different. You'll probably just notice it sooner with the Seche Vite because you'll be using it ALL THE TIME!
  151. I LOVE THIS PRODUCT. IT DRIES FAST AND I LOVE THE SHINE. THE NAIL POLISH SEEMS TO LAST LONGER AND I FEEL IT MAKES MY NAILS FEEL STRONGER. I WON'T BUY ANY OTHER DRY FAST TOP COAT.

  155. If you paint your nails in any sort of serious capacity, you've probably heard of SV. I find that there are some minor flaws with the product, but it works better than any other brand I've used thus far.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Beautiful, glossy finish.<br />Dries very fast.<br />Can be applied over wet polish.<br />Protects your manicure to give it some staying power.<br />If you're stamping, it won't smear your stamps (let it dry just a bit first) and it keeps it looking nice and intact.<br /><br />Cons:<br />Some polishes are more susceptible to peeling when SV has been applied. Not chipping or flaking - the edges lift and literally the entire coat of polish will peel clean off. These are polishes that do not peel otherwise. It seems to happen most in conjunction with OPI polishes.<br />You may need to replace it sooner than you think. After about 6 months and with half a bottle left, my last bottle started drying so quickly that I couldn't even get it on the nail. A fresh bottle resolved this, and it's not like it's terribly pricy to replace.<br /><br />Overall it is a very good product that will give you very nice results. If you enjoy painting your nails you really need this in your arsenal!

  168. This is the absolute best topcoat ever made. I'm always thrilled with it! A few important tips. First, you MUST apply this gently, while your base color is still wet. The best way is to get a bead of Seche Vite on the end of your brush, and gently smooth it over your nail. You may end up with a tiny bit of shrinkage of the color around your cuticle and edge of your nails, but I personally have not. I've heard some people do. Second, if you're planning on painting on art of some kind (polka dots, stripes, whatever your fancy), I do my base color, then Seche Vite, my art, then more Seche Vite. I swear, five minutes after I put 3 or 4 coats of polish and this miracle, I can do laundry without a single smudge or smear! I can finish my nails, then leave right away for work. My ONLY gripe about it, is that about halfway through the bottle, it thickens almost too much to use. Its really nothing that a little polish thinner can't fix though. Overall, this always gets me compliments on my nails. It has a shellac finish that lasts until I intentionally remove it with polish remover. The easiest way is to unroll a cotton ball, then tear it in half down the middle. Then tear off 10 pieces from that one cotton ball. Pour some remover into the cap from the bottle, dip one end of each piece into the remover, and place each one on your nails. Let it sit for a minute, and all the polish wipes away in one simple swipe (I always use pure acetone. It may take a minute longer with regular remover)!<br />Hope this helps my fellow polish addicts!
  169. Love this fast nail coat. It dries very easy and quick. It keeps my nail polish looking nice and bright. I will buy more.
  170. I really like this top coat but lately I have been double guessing myself. Dries very fast but sometimes clumps on the sides.
  171. Why is this so expensive at salons and so cheap online?? This stuff is one of my favorite beauty products. Never smudge your nails again!!
  172. I usually were OPI fast dry top coat but found that it gets thick very fast, and I have to purchase a new one. I asked the clerk at my local Beauty First what she recommended and she said most definitely Seche Vite. I am utterly disappointed. The top coat I put on my toes has lasted over a week. That is good. Second, it does dry fast. I put it over a french manicure and it lasted 2 days before chipping. Then I used it as just a base coat until I could get a color on my nails. It started PEELING, yes, the whole coat peeled right off, the same evening. I paid $10 for this and expect a much better product. Very disappointed. I thought maybe you were only supposed to put one coat on (I did two) but after reading some of the other review I do not think that is the case. I will be taking it back. Oh yah, and it really has a bad odor too!

I came to find that it is one of the best nail products I have ever used. What a great surprise!!! It lives up to its promise of drying fast and makes my color last forever and look amazing. People are always asking me if I've had a fresh manicure and complimenting my nails. I never review products but this one really deserves a great one. You won't be disappointed!!! Plus, the price is almost too good to be true!

  186. best top coat there is
  187. I used to wear polish every single day -- then I had kids & never had time anymore. 12 years later, I have now started researching polishes & top/base coats. Bought a bottle of Stickey & a bottle of Seche Vite. Used a good polish -- which was also fast dry so I probably wouldn't have needed a top coat, except everyone recommended it. Did my nails on Saturday -- base, 2 coats of color, Seche top -- & yes my nails dried fast & were super shiny. But within 24 hours, they were already chipping & peeling. And I didn't even do any dishes in that time. Very disappointed -- so my search for a good fast drying top coat continues.
  188. This stuff is incredible! It dries super fast, leaving a nice and professional high gloss finish. The problem is it doesn't last long! You really do have to try it to believe it. This quick dry is a life saver for a busy girl and mom. Put the babies to sleep, redo your polish, and go to sleep yourself! In drug stores this runs about $9.99 and it would be worth every penny, but... Wet n Wild's 99cent topcoat actually does a better job preserving a manicure! Just from scratching your head over night in your sleep, you may very well see slightly worn tips in the morning depending. By day 2-3, your nails appear to be over due for a manicure. If you enjoy frequent color changes, this might not be a problem at all! For me it's either this or risk waking up with fabric prints in my polish (meaning I'll have to redo/remove my polish anyway). I've tried this over Essie, OPI, and L'oreal. Each time the problem with wear is the same. I'm guessing this quick wearing process is due to it drying into one solid coat with the nail polish beneath (according to the description in the packaging). Naturally, the quick wear and frequent mini manicures mean the bottle doesn't last very long. Since I wasn't too keen on changing my polish every two days like clockwork, I decided to try quick dries by a few other companies. Compared to Salley Hansen, Out The Door, and Essie, Seche Vite comes out on top if you really don't want to wait. Out the door is the runner up. The Sally Hansen and Essie I returned to the store as they cannot be applied to wet polish without messing up a manicure. Out the Door preserves a manicure slightly longer than Seche Vite, but there is a problem with drying time. Out the Door may feel dry on top, yet not be totally dry underneath. Because of this, when I used Out the Door 50% of the times I woke up the next day with fabric prints in at least one of my nails. This happened even when I polished my nails an hour or two before bed, and waited a few minutes between coats. Seche Vite was the only one I tried that *completely* dried in minutes. Unlike Seche Vite, with Out the Door you may end up with bubbles if you apply it too heavily. So, to get the shine of Seche Vite without the bubbles, you may need to apply two thinner coats of Out the Door. With Seche Vite, which goes on heavily, you still have to watch out for bubbles once you're 3/4 through the bottle. (I haven't tried using a polish thinner to know if it resolved the problem without reducing its effectiveness.) While I hate that Seche Vite wears on the tips so easily, and it also gets goopy once you're halfway through the bottle, I've been spoiled already by the super fast drying time! I'm now on bottle number 2 and this stuff is a keeper!
  189. I mix and match different brands, because I've found that within a single brand will always have some polishes that chip easily and some that look good and last. I always use an ORLY Color Blast glitter polish on the top half of my nails before applying Seche Vite top coat. I also wait 12 hours or so after applying the polish before putting on a final Seche Vite top coat, because I found that this somehow makes the polish last significantly longer before chipping/bubbling... Here are the polishes I've used with this: - Ciate with Seche Vite lasts 5~10 days - Sally Hansen Xtreme Wear with Seche Vite lasts 7~12 days.. Basically minimal chipping all the way until my nails have grown out from the base enough that it looks bad and I remove it all. - OPI (silver polish) lasts 3~5 days. I'm pretty sure this is the fault of the OPI polish and not this top coat, seeing as the other brands/colors last a long time. So this top coat is working very well with the routines I have so far. :O I'm not sure which polish is improving the longevity more, but everything put together is working! So that's that! More random notes: - dries in under 2 minutes - smooth, glossy feel... can apply a thick, smooth coat or a thin one. Either works well. - completely colorless

  204. After reading many reviews I decided I had to try this top coat for myself. I must say that overall I truly love it. The one downside is that it has a very strong smell. Much stronger than any top coat I have used.<br /><br />*update* I have had this for a while now and the one downside is it no longer applies easily. It seems thicker even and is very stringy as I apply. It's practically impossible to apply it evenly now.   205. I have to say that this product seems great. It dries quickly; however, you still have to be delicate with your nails. I've read that after 5 minutes of applying the product you should be able to resume normal activity. That's DEFINITELY not the case. I did this to test it and managed to severely smudge the tips of two of my fingers (right pointer and left thumb). It does dry to a glossy, \\"wet\\" finish. HOWEVER, I can't say that I'm going to continue to use this product. I got a VERY annoying humming in my ears while using this product. It was loud and very uncomfortable. I looked up symptoms of exposure to toluene and it said ringing in the ears was one of them. I thought using the product on my nails wouldn't be a big deal but this ear problem really bothered me. I wouldn't recommend buying the product for this exact reason. Find something that is \\"Big 3 Free.\\"

I then checked my other nails and they were dry too!!<br /><br />So, I give this a 5/5 for how fast it dries. It however doesn't end there I promise.   236. I know I am in the minority but I do not care for Seche Vite at all. The first thing you will notice when you open the bottle is the odor - it is overwhelming and gives me a headache after only moments. It smells because it contains Toluene - one of the \\"big 3's\\" that most polish companies have removed from their lacquers and treatments. Because of the toluene Seche Vite simply does not work with Big 3 Free polishes. You will notice your polish shrinking on the edges as it dries, and that your manicures just don't last. As you get down to the second half of the bottle, the product starts to thicken considerably which makes it hard to spread onto your nails. You will notice as this happens that when you apply it onto your wet polish the polish will drag, wrinkle, and look streaky.<br /><br />Just a note- You MUST apply Seche Vite to wet polish. Wait no more than a couple minutes before you apply it or your polish will come off in a big sheet. You cannot use it to \\"refresh\\" the shine on a manicure you've been wearing for a couple days as that will make it come off in a sheet as well.<br /><br />What kills it for me is the smell. I just can't get past it and that is why I will not purchase this product again. If you are looking for a good quick dry top coat that is shiny and gives you the glassy look that Seche Vite does, I recommend Poshe Super Fast Drying Top Coat. It has some of the problems Seche Vite does (must apply to wet polish, starts to thicken as you use up the bottle), but I do believe it is much, much better.

  252. I've been using Seche Vite Top Coat for about 3 months (the same bottle), and I change my nail polish on average about every 4 days. I honestly find the bad reviews of this product unfathomable. It really is the best. It dries fast, like really, really fast. On one of my first uses of it I let it dry for about 15 minutes and then tapped my thumbnail hard with the tip of another nail. No dents, unbelievable. It has a high-shine gloss that wears beautifully.<br /><br />I see complaints of shrinkage in a lot of reviews. I have never experienced this. No gaps, no shrinkage. And this is over Essie, China Glaze, OPI, Nicole, and some $2 drugstore brands. I make sure to paint all the way to the tip of the nail and over, and never have any issues. It is really thick though, so if you let your nails grow out (or they grow fast) you might see a ridge from the edge of it at the bottom of your nail. To the reviewer that says it's garbage that a top coat can be applied incorrectly: well, no it's not. You definitely have to follow the instructions and apply this while your polish is still somewhat tacky. I don't know how it works, but it seems to mix with the tacky polish and harden into a shell. It also smooths out the polish as it does this, hiding nail pits, ridges, or mistakes. If you apply it to completely dry polish you will see a noticeable difference in performance. My friend did her nails at my house and told me she didn't like the top coat. The next time she came over I told her she had to put in on while her nails were still a bit wet. She did, and raved to me about her glossy nails 5 days later. Pretty much as soon as you finish painting the last nail, open your Seche Vite and start applying. I can get a manicure to last 4-5 days without chipping, which is a miracle to me considering the abuse my hands (and nails) take at my job. It's a record.<br /><br />This product does, however, smell REALLY bad. Use in a well-ventilated area and happy painting.
  253. When it says dry fast, it isn't kidding. Without this, your nails might be &#34;dry&#34;, but not really - when you run your fingers over the nail, it's dry at a light touch, but then clearly it isn't dry underneath. This changes that - it's either dry, or not. Of course, I'd still let it dry as long as possible just to ensure that your nails are done, but this top coat definitely prevents the accidental smudging. It also gives the nail a nice shiny finish. Definitely Recommend!

And it does dry very fast which is great when you don't have a lot of time to sit without using your hands.   256. This product does what it says it will do! It dried my 4 layers of polish quickly and completely. It is very shiny and super hard. No chips at 3 days despite having thin, weak, previously covered in acrylic nails. I type all day long and then do dishes by hand at night...no weakening of this product. I am also a recovering nail biter and would recommend this to anyone trying to quit. It keeps the nails looking so good and they feel so different that the urge to bite disappears when my teeth touch my nails. Awesome product!!
  257. My favorite top coat. Long lasting and shiny.
  258. It's very shiny. Dries very fast. Even dries the polish underneath. Great price. Go ahead, get it. three more words
  259. This product does dry nails fast, but do not go out and pick cotton or do heavy duty stuff for an hour or so.<br />I like it because it does dry fast, but within the limitations of normal work. You could type or do light work. Just don't plan on repelling down a mountain too soon.
  260. ******REVIEW EDIT BELOW******<br /><br />I've been sold on a Sally Hansen Mega Shine top coat but I've been hearing a lot of buzz about Seche Vite. People all over Youtube were using it so I figured it must be good. After being thoroughly impressed with what I was reading about this product I finally purchased some. I wanted to like this but there isn't a good thing I can say about it. It dries duller than dishwater. When it finally does dry, which takes a whole lot longer than advertised, it dries to the consistency of rubber plastic. You could flake, scratch and peel the whole thing off like melted candy. Even if you used a halfway decent polish this stuff will corrupt the integrity of the whole look. Ok, so what if I just got a bad batch of it? For what these people set as the asking price for this stuff there should be no roulette wheel of chance when buying. Terrible waste of money.<br /><br />EDIT: Ok I gave this another shot some time later and it seems to work fine. I don't know why it was such a dud the first time I tried it out of the box but luckily I didn't throw it out. I've been using it on all my complex manicures lately and it's pretty good stuff. It works better than my Sally Hansen Mega Shine when you are painting on layers and layers of polish to make crazy embellishments. If you've got trendy designs and chunky pieces you want to attach to your nails this stuff will dry everything up pretty quickly. To my eye though it doesn't shine quite as well as SH. For touch ups I still use SH but Seche Vite is good for finishing complicated nail designs when you don't have time to sit around for hours waiting for it to dry. It is basically clear goo that hardens quickly.

  264. I do my own acrylics at home, but when they dry their matte. I tried using my regular top coat on them but it dries inconsistently leaving the acrylic looking bumpy and messy. So I looked into gel top coats and UV lights. Some of the top coats I looked at where cheaper than this, and stated here was no use for a UV light. I really wanted to try an air dry gel top coat before purchasing a UV lamp. This top coat had the highest rating and the best reviews. It was more expensive than other options, but due to the consistent reviews stating &#34;fast drying,&#34; and &#34;glossy gel finish,&#34; I decided to give this one a try. This morning I did my acrylics and then applied this top coat, and I am so extremely happy with the results! No need for a UV lamp, and gives my acrylic nails the shiny gel finish that you'd get at a salon. Now I truly have salon quality acrylic nails done right in my own home. Take it from someone who is a really hesitant buyer, is extremely cautious with her money, and does a lot of research before buying. This top coat is worth every penny spent. Looks amazing on acrylics, and though I haven't used it on regular polish yet, I imagine it will work and look just as great! I will be buying more!!!

  306. I bought some OPI Top Coat and Drip Dry to go with it, but I wasn't pleased with the results. With the Drip Dry my nails would dry to the touch in less than a minute, but they didn't get really hard for a few hours. I went to bed a hour after doing my nails and they had marks in the morning. Someone recommended Seche Vite as an alternative, so I purchased some. It's amazing. Dry to the touch in a minute or less, and hard enough to resist damage in less than 30 minutes. It seems to be best if applied when the top color coat is still wet. Several reviews say they've had chipping problems, but I haven't had that problem yet, even over a few days. I have read that applying it over color coats that are too dry will lead to the chipping and peeling. I would recommend getting a bottle of Seche Restore to go along with this. It does tend to get gloopy, and the Seche Restore will fix it right up. I've read that Seche Restore is fantastic for thinning out all brands of nail polish as well, but I haven't tried that yet. Even with the gloopy issue, I'll continue to purchase Seche Vite. The fact that I can do a quick manicure and get on with the things I need to do without worrying about my nails getting messed up makes it worth the minor inconvenience of having to keep another product around to thin it out. This product allows me to do my nails more often, because it makes the whole process FAST!

The formula is so thick that when you use multiple coats during the week it becomes noticeable on your nails. I had a lot tip wear from the shrinkage and peeling especially near the cuticle. There was very little chipping but the shrinkage, peeling and tip wear were problematic. I have since switched to Out the Door top coat with Essie protein base coat. I am going on day 5 with one tiny chip that is barely noticeable , no shrinkage or tip wear. Seche Vite may work for you as it has for many but I've found Out the Door to work much better.

  351. Okay, Seche Vite is cheap. But you get what you pay for. It leaves yucky whiteness around the edges of my polish and completely ruins my manis after a few days. I use OPI and China Glaze polish as well as China Glaze and CND Stickey base coats. I have tried different base coats in an effort to figure out what was making the edges of my polish look horrible. I finally realized it's the Seche Vite top coat. The Seche Vite causes my nail polish to shrink at the bottom, the sides, AND the tips, making my carefully applied polish look sloppy and uneven and gross. So after a few days, when I have to reapply the Seche Vite because the first day shine wears off, my polish just starts looking worse and worse. Someone on here said in their review that \\"when applied correctly\\" Seche Vite works great. That's a load of garbage. How do you apply a top coat incorrectly?? You just brush it on. That's the extent of \\"application.\\" Seche Vite just plain sucks. I don't understand how it got to be so popular, other than the fact that it's cheap. So it dries quickly. Well, it dries the outside of the polish quickly. It's dry to the touch after about 15 minutes, as with most other fast drying top coat products. But it still takes between an hour and two hours for the entire polish job to dry completely. I still have to be very careful for an hour or two to not bump my nails into anything. That is just too much time to sit around with wet nails. I used my Seche Vite for around eight manicures, and then it got all gloopy. Someone in the reviews said to buy some restorer product. I'm going to spend extra money to make something work like it should? I don't think so. I'm giving it three stars because it does seem to keep my polish from getting chipped. But I think that's mostly because I use quality polish. I used a Sinful Colors under Seche Vite once and it chipped right away. But I'll give Seche Vite the benefit of the doubt. I'm done with Seche Vite. I'll never buy another bottle. I'mmoving on to other top coats. And by the way, if you do end up buying this product despite my warnings, then fine. But for the love of Mike, don't waste your money on the Seche Vite base coat. Now THAT is an entirely worthless, one star product.

  361. Works well and an amazing price
  362. I purchased this Seche Vite top coat from amazon about two - three months ago. I wanted to use it for awhile to give the best review possible. For starters. I used to have such problems with nail polish. I could literally paint my nails and sit for 30+ minutes and then THREE-FOUR HOURS later go to bed and wake up with sheet marks/imprints all over the place. Being a recovering perfectionist, it drove me nuts to spend all that time painting my nails to have it destroyed by smudges and nicks and you name it, even hours later. Who has that many hours to be careful with your nails? I constantly was touching something that destroyed my nails. This product truly fixes that problem. Within 15 minutes (sometimes less!) of painting my nails, it's dry and I can touch it and not worry. I can even go digging around in my purse. It looks pretty flawless with this glassy top coat. I no longer get sheet marks. I've changed my nail polish about every week and I'm able to do that because I can get it done in 20-30 minutes total with base coat, color coat, and this top coat without taking such a huge chunk of time. Now you do have to be realistic with yourself. If you impale a nail on something hard and metallic after painting it or something it still can leave some imprint, and showering or having your nails in hot water soon after will soften the polish and leave you vulnerable to dents and nicks. But that aside, you really can do just about anything without worrying too much within 15 minutes and by 20-30 you should be pretty solid for typically manicure destroying tasks (even dishes). Again be realistic, thin coats will dry better. If you gob on a ton of nail polish and a ton of the top coat it will take longer to set and you might goof them up and be disappointed. It holds up pretty well for a good week possibly more. And let me tell you my nails go through hell. I work retail and I'm constantly taking security sensor tags with pointy pins off clothing and grabbing handfuls of plastic sensors at night to put them away into our backstock. We also have hangers with metal clips (like for pants, skirts, etc) and again I have to go digging around in bins of those and am constantly banging and scratching up my nails. The top coat may get a little scratched on the surface but I haven't had ANY major chips or nicks and it's held up really well. One day I even felt my nails were starting to look scratched up and a customer complimented how great and shiny my nails looked (go figure). I've also had people ask me if I got one of those gel manicures professionally done! Nope, all this great little product. When I have to change it at the end of the week it's because of growout or because it's pulled away a little from the tips of my nails. One odd thing is that I have noticed by then end of one week, the nailpolish looks a tiny bit darker than when I first painted them so there might be an issue with discoloration. I also recommend making sure you get the sides of your nails. This product is thick and you'll have a visible ridge if you didn't quite cover the whole nail. It does set pretty quickly too so there is a little bit of an art to putting on enough so that you can cover the nail before it sets without globbing on so much that it won't dry, but I got the hang of it pretty quickly. There is also a slight chemically smell to the product but I'm pretty sensitive to smell and it doesn't bother me because it fades quickly. I remember reading reviews about it getting overly thick, and I did purchase the restoring drops from seche vite but so far I haven't needed to use them. So it doesn't seem as big of an issue as some reviews would suggest. Overall the product is amazing and gives you flawless looking nails that and usable within such a short period of time. I have almost forgotten the days of sheet marks and horrible smudges and I get compliments all the time and I keep recommending it to all my friends. Ican't believe people don't know about this top coat, I refuse to paint my nails without it now! It's really fantastic and makes at home manicures very accessible.

  385. I work in a nursing home, so I'm constantly washing my hands and changing gloves, and this is by far the BEST top coat I've ever used, and I've used a TON. In my opinion it works best with a glitter colors, since glitters, for me, are super hard to remove anyway. I use ORLY Binder as my basecoat, then put my color on. I hear a lot of people say to put Seche over wet nails, but for me that doesn't work. I give them a minute or two, to where they're still tacky but not super wet, then put it on, and seal the free edge. Viola. I have always had thin, egg-shell nails. They bend and break really easily, and growing them out is a b***h-and-a-half. But with Biotin pills and Seche, I can keep them at a much longer length than usual. I really like that when it dries, you can hold your nail up to your face, sideways, and actually see how thick the polish is. Reminds me of gels. Normally polish only lasts a day or two, even before I worked in a nursing home. Now I can get a full week out of my manicure, so long as I make sure to re-wrap the free edge every third day or so. I totally, totally recommend this! As for the &#34;dangerous chemicals&#34; in it....I figure there's 101 ways to get cancer, and unless you're practically bathing in this stuff, this small of an exposure really shouldn't be a big deal. But that's just my 2 cents. :) My only COMPLAINTS are that it gets goopy really fast. I've never used a polish thinner, so I'm not sure if it would work with the Seche brand. But I mean, for the price, I just got 2 bottles...I use the goopier one to do my free edge. Seems to be working just as well. Also it's kind of hard to get off with polish remover. But again, one afternoon of removing stubborn polish, instant dry-time, and a full week or more of a perfect manicure is SO worth it IMO.

  404. For so long, I would only paint my nails occasionally. The process took me so long, and it ended up getting messed up more often than not, so it just didn't seem worth it most of the time.<br /><br />Recently, though, I started reading nail polish blogs and found two tips that have made all the difference for me. One was how to clean up the polish using a brush, and the other was Seche Vite for a top coat.<br /><br />For me, Seche Vite works wonders. Before, I had times where I would finish painting my nails four hours before going to bed, and STILL end up with sheet marks in my polish the next morning. With the Seche Vite, I've been able to change a diaper or put my toddler in his carseat 5 - 10 minutes after applying it without ruining my polish job.<br /><br />Also, and this is something I've never experienced with other top coats I've tried... it seems to perfect my polish job. I don't know how to explain it, but I've had goopy, lumpy applications from thickened polish, and after I go over it with the Seche Vite, it looks I applied it perfectly. It almost seems like it melts the top layer of polish and helps it to level itself out. I'm not sure if that's the best way to describe it... it sounds scary, but it's a good thing.<br /><br />I have read that it co-operates with some polishes better than others. I'm wearing Essie right now, and it looks perfect after a day and a half. Other times I've used it I've gotten some shrinkage (that MIGHT have had to do with me applying it after the polish was dry, I'm not sure).<br /><br />Hope that helps.

  411. I originally gave this only 1 star. I've done some reading and figured out the secret to this stuff to keep it from peeling and to make your manicure last. 1 - As soon as you're done with your last coat of polish on your first hand, apply this top coat before you move on to applying the second coat to your other hand. This top coat needs to be put on right after your last coat of polish, the polish needs to be good and wet still. 2 - Do not use this as your base coat as well, that's not what it's intended for and it will peel! 3 - I've tried using this with my Sally Hansen base coat and no base coat. My manicure peels within a day after using a base coat. I've found this polish works best without a base. However, there may be other base coats out there such as OPI, etc. that will work OK and not cause your polish to peel using this top coat. (I've not heard good things about the Seche Vite Base) This top coat dries super fast, your manicure will be completely dry within 5 minutes. Just remember to get it on there while your nails are still super wet!

  466. This stuff works really well for me. The thing you need to keep in mind with this that I had to learn is that you really need to apply it to nails that are still wet. If you wait until the polish dries and then apply it, it tends to shrink and pull away from the cuticles which looks weird and then leads to chipping. Apply it while polish is still wet and your poilish will dry pretty fast and it makes a nice protective top coat.

I was still very careful with my fingers for a bit afterwards, but within a couple of minutes my nail were totally dry. The polish stays on longer as a result and chips less in the first day or two.   489. I absolutely love Seche Vite. My polish dried quickly and didn't give me enough time to do anything to ruin my manicure the way I normally do. I like to do my nails at home because I'm lucky enough to have a steady hand and I don't like paying someone to do something that I can do myself. Seche Vite dries fast enough to counteract my clumsiness, and it dries to a really incredible shine. I get compliments on my nails all the time.<br /><br />I've read through some of the comments on here, and here are a few observations I've noticed. First of all, if your Seche Vite is chipping or gets too thick, buy the Seche Restore. A few drops will restore your topcoat. DO NOT use nail polish remover, you need the Restore because it will add back in the chemicals that is used in the topcoat.<br /><br />As for Seche Vite not working with three-free polishes, I pretty much exclusively use Zoya nail polish, and I do not have a problem with using Seche Vite as the topcoat. For those who are encountering problems with shrinkage due to their polish being three-free, it might be a good idea to let the polish dry completely. The chemicals evaporating out of the actual nail enamel does so at a slower rate than the toulene in Seche Vite, so that could be what is causing the shrinkage.<br /><br />Overall, this is a must have for me. I'm completely sold and I don't think I'll ever switch to another topcoat.
  490. I don't do my nails (I'm a guy), so I don't really know if they are good for nails or not.   529. I am a mommy to a very hyperactive toddler and this top coat is amazing for me. Being a parent means you have very little time to sit around and wait for polish to dry. You could spend 10 minutes on your perfect mani and ruin it the second you stick your hands in the washer to get out your laundry or the second you pick up your kiddo. This dries to an indestructible hardness in about 2 minutes, and will not be ruined 5 minutes later when you have to hand wash dishes for half an hour.<br /><br />I would say this is more ideal for people who need their top coat to dry quickly, but don't mind changing their polish frequently. I change mine about every other day and this top coat holds up well for 2 days and then begins to chip away. One thing I have noticed is that it will last longer if your polish is fewer layers. 1 or 2 layers of polish will hold up really well, but if you layer on 4-5 coats of polish and then put this top coat on (which is very often done because it will even harden those really thick gummy manis very quickly) then it probably will not hold up as well as if you used it on 1-2 polish coats. Also, the odor on this stuff is SOOO strong. I was about 10 feet away from it and the chemical smell was so strong so please do your best to use it outside or in well-ventilated areas.<br /><br />Overall, I'm really happy with this product. Yes, it does chip fairly easily after a couple of days but imo, if you are changing your polish regularly its really not that big of a deal. I have saved a ton of time thanks to this stuff, and it makes painting my nails a possibility again even when I am short on time.

  583. I've been using this product for a couple of years now. Very happy that I could purchase directly from this merchant. Would definitely purchase again.
  584. Seche Vite is incredibly popular on beauty blogs and websites, and rightfully so- sort of.<br /><br />It does dry incredibly quickly. That's no exaggeration. You apply it when the nail polish is still wet, and then it dries it all. By the time I finish painting the second hand, the first hand is dry. That part is amazing. Will it still smudge? Yes, it's dry but not set.<br /><br />It does resist sheet marks and pillow lines. That's also impressive, you can paint before bed and wake up without linen tire tracks cutting through the shine.<br /><br />It does give a very &#34;wet&#34; look. It glistens and shines and you end up staring at your hands far more than is socially acceptable.<br /><br />But- as it dries, it pulls in from the edges. Even if you make sure to paint from edge to edge, after a day, you'll see a gap between the edge of the top coat and the skin of your finger. Tips start to show too, so it pulls in and shrinks from all directions.<br />It also peels. it doesn't chip, which is great, but when it wants to come off, it comes off all at once in a giant sheet. Some people on blogs and sites say that this happens due to applying Seche Vite either too early- when the polish is still too wet- or too late, when the polish is too dry. I experimented with both and couldn't stop it from happening.<br /><br />Overall, it's good- it's shiny, it's quick, it's pretty- but I'd rather have chips than lose entire nails at once.
  585. I got this a week ago and I just want to say it makes my cheap nail polish last sooo much longer[week to two week range bro] and makes it shiner as well. Like you feel like Cruella de vil with your shiny nails. Seriously and when the polish does come off it comes off kinda like tape. It's very hard to remove without remover. One tip though, apply this to your nail polish when it's set or gummy not completely sopping wet or your manicure will look like crap. HAPPY PAINTING! <3

  760. This is it. This is the only top coat you'll ever want. This is the top coat you've been looking for, the magical make-it-stay-and-dry-it-fast dream polish people talk about. This. It. It.<br /><br />So I love painting my nails. I have small hands, tiny nails and an obsession with nail art. I also am constantly cooking, washing dishes, cleaning and stress picking at my nails, so I feel like up til now, no home-done manicure lasts more than three days. And if you put two hours into the effort of doing your nails, you kind of want your end results to last more than Monday to Wednesday, if you're lucky.<br /><br />The answer to a longer lasting manicure? Seche Vite -- and Gelous polish, but that's another review for another time.<br /><br />This product has a very strong, chemical scent. I rather like such smells, so it doesn't bother me but if you're sensitive use a well ventilated area to do your manicure. I find that once I've applied my colored polish, I can wait about a minute, then apply Seche Vite with an almost instantaneous drying, sealing effect. Cheaper polishes can run a little on the Seche Vite brush, so you may want to wait longer for that polish to set. Also wait a little longer for nail art designs like ombre nails, multilayer colors or additions like striping tape, shaped dough cut outs or stones. Five or so minutes should do it, then gently and quickly apply your Seche Vite. Another really loved effect of this polish is that it creates a solid, almost gel-like topcoat. My nails are nice and firm, very shiny and my manicure now lasts about a week. Yay!<br /><br />I have noticed a little thickening of the polish, and while I haven't tried it yet I think a polish thinner could keep my bottle happy and usable for a while.<br /><br />I am definitely, absolutely buying this product again. And again. And again. Seche Vite -- I love you!<br /><br />-JR-

  791. I'm addicted to nail art and this top coat is serious business. It is completely indispensible to the process. It brings out the colors and designs and it doesn't just make my nails shine, it makes them gleam like the top of the Chrysler building, and seals everything. It also dries really fast.   792. Well, I had heard a lot about Seche Vite and was a little skeptical. While it will take several days more before I can comment on Chip resistance, let me just say that this is much shinier than any other fast drying top coat I have tried, and the equal of some high gloss coats. My other fast drying top coats have now been demoted to doing pedicures.<br /><br />Edited two years later: Well, the honeymoon period is over, and I've moved on to other top coats, most notably HK Girl Glisten&Glow.<br /><br />Seche has a couple of problems.<br /><br />Thickening - By the time your bottle is half empty, the polish will have thickened to the point where it doesn't go on smoothly and evenly. To thin it, however, you will need to buy Seche Vite thinner, others may cause the polish to fog up and no longer be opaque.<br /><br />Shrinking - Shrinking can be a random problem. You'll know a polish has shrunk when the edges have a ridge-like appearance instead of blending down smoothly to that thin line of visible nail next to the cuticle. Which leads to<br /><br />Doesn't work well over dry polish - While Seche shrinks randomly over damp polish, it almost ALWAYS shrinks over dry polish. It smears nail art. Pulls decals up. And for those who like to keep their nails fresh by adding a top coat every two days or so, not working over dry polish is a deal breaker.
  793. As a mom to two little ones, I need polish to cure quickly (actually harden, not just surface dry!!!) or I can do it at all- there's just no time! This is the only product that works! The only draw back is that after a few days the polish will peel away from the nails. I just deal with it- there's no alternative!
  794. It gets goopy halfway through and becomes useless. I wish that wasn't the case because I really liked it at the beginning!
  795. Dies really fast and a good shine.

It adds such gloss and shine, it looks great!

But I found this on sale at Sally's for like $4 and bought it.<br /><br />I could not be any happier with this product. It dries super fast and that is awesome for me because I have very little patience. I always end up putting away all my manicure supplies after waiting about a minute instead of waiting for my nails to dry and ALWAYS end up smearing my nail polish and putting dents in it. But this stuff dries so fast I don't have to worry about that.<br /><br />It is not 100% dry in seconds though. You still have to wait before putting away laundry or things that would typically damage partially dry nails. The top is dry but the stuff underneath is not. So its easy to put ripples in your nails from the polish sliding if you run it over something. I typically do my nails about 20 mins or so before going to bed and the top coat is dry enough that it causes no problems and the bottom stuff is dry by morning so my manicure is fully set.<br /><br />I've also read a lot of complaints about it chipping super easy. I have not noticed chipping any more than with a typical top coat. My nails peel pretty bad though and I still have that issue but I found out recently OPI makes a Nail Envy base coat specifically to fix that so I'll probably try that with my Seche Vite and I'm sure that will help.

  1190. I've noticed the skin around my nail bed is drying and peeling after use. Here's what I found online after looking up the ingredients:<br /><br />Health Hazards: Butyl acetate vapors may cause dizziness or drowsiness. Continued use of a product containing butyl acetate may cause skin to crack and become dry.<br /><br />Here's warning label on the box:<br />WARNING: \\"This product contains a chemical known to the state of California to cause birth defects or other reproductive harm.\\"<br /><br />Online:<br />Butyl Acetate (main ingredient) can also be narcotic in high concentrations.<br /><br />The next ingredient is Toluene. Here's what I found online:<br />Symptoms of toluene exposure include: irritation of the eyes and nose; weakness, exhaustion, confusion, euphoria, dizziness, headache; dilated pupils, lacrimation (discharge of tears); anxiety, muscle fatigue, insomnia; numbness or tingling of the skin; dermatitis. Toluene exposure may cause liver and kidney damage.<br /><br />Toluene affects the central nervous system, eyes, skin, respiratory system, liver, kidneys. Breathing high levels of toluene during pregnancy has been shown to result in children with birth defects and to retard mental abilities and growth. There is evidence that exposure to toluene at work is associated with spontaneous abortion.<br /><br />High concentrations of toluene, usually from use in a confined space or unventilated area, can cause loss of consciousness, respiratory depression and death. Long term and repeated workplace exposure to toluene affect the central nervous system.<br /><br />Of course, most of these things occur only with acute exposure, so 'they' say.<br /><br />Well, the stuff works, that's no lie. But really, this may have put me over my beauty carcinogenic limit for the month.

I used it over wet and dry polish, I prefer using over dry because if you apply it over wet polish (which is the correct way to use it I think) the brush picks up a bit of the colored polish and can tint the entire bottle.<br /><br />It seemed to dry fast and leaves a glassy, high shine layer. I needed two coats on slightly shimmery polish, because the shimmer particles were a bit bumpy I guess. That's not too bad though considering I usually use 3 or 4 costs with other polishes, which ends up looking much too thick.<br /><br />For the price this is a great top coat.   1263. Before I bought this product, I looked for reviews of fast dry clear coats. Previously I had used Sally Hansen's hard as nails line, which when dry, is very nice and helps with growing longer nails, but takes longer to dry than I am patient. Invariably I'd do something once I thought the polish was dry, and end up smudging it. So frustrating! I was tired of smudges with every single color change or touch up, but then I read good stuff about this product. Boy oh boy, it was all true, and then some! It comes off the brush looking thick, but it glides onto the nail perfectly. It DOES dry fast; very quickly your nails are dry to the touch. I only had a tiny bit of trouble when I tried to put this product over really wet nail polish (don't do that.) Since it's thick, it tends to drag on very wet polish. If your polish has dried even a little, then it works fine. Once in place, it does. not. smudge. I love it!<br /><br />I wasn't prepared for what a gorgeous finish it puts on your nails: high gloss, a thick but not too thick clear layer, smooth smooth smooth, and it even evened out some knubbly areas where my polish had clumped as it dried. I think some people call those bubbles. The Seche Vite top coat had the effect of softening any mistakes in the polish and letting the colored polish underneath flow into a more perfectly smooth layer. A couple chips I had touched up with a complementary color, creating an ombre effect, and adding this top coat let the color edges soften into each other even better. It looks fantastic -- like a salon effect. I had one smudge that I pushed back into place, but without the topcoat it was blatently obvious I'd had an accident with half-wet half-dry polish. Later in the day after putting this topcoat over it, you'd only know there had been a smudge if I pointed it out to you. I love that. Wow, who invented this stuff? Give them an award!<br /><br />I wasn't sure I'd want to use a topcoat all the time, but when something makes your manicure look amazing, and makes doing it easier, I'm sold. Sold, sold, sold! I'll be a Seche Vite Dry Fast top coat user forever.<br /><br />Absolutely worth the five bucks I spent. Maybe worth more. I am so glad I tried it.   1273. Seche Vite dries super fast, with a smooth glassy finish. Before using this product, if i painted my nails 2 hours before bed, I would wake up with sheet marks on my nails. Seche Vite helps to dry your nails to the base, and you won't wake up with sheet marks. I have recommended this product to all my friends.
  1274. Great Product! I was skeptical at first, but if you do it right - as instructed then you can't beat it. Don't be stingy with it or you will have to re paint the nails from scratch.   1275. This top coat isn't 100% perfect, but it does what it claims. It dries CRAZY fast (hence e name...) and leaves my nails looking glossy and fresh for days. My girlfriends have all been asking me where I get my nails done and they're surprised that I DIY it! Ive recommended it to all of them.<br /><br />My only real complaint is that sometimes one of my nails will chip off in one big chunk, leaving me with a naked nail. I guess that happens because the top coat bonds so much to the polish? Also, be careful not to put your color on too thick or Seche Vite will dry in weird waves. Two to three regular coats are good.<br /><br />To minimize chipping I brush on a coat every couple days.<br /><br />I couldn't believe how fast this stuff dries my nails. You can literally fish around in your bag a couple minutes later. Buy with confidence!
  1276. I've been a nail tech for three years. I've gone through many polish bottles and fast drying products. I have to say that this dry fast top coat is superb. As a top coat, I love it. This product does not give me that problem. I cannot get over how shiny this makes my nails look. The drying time for my nails is usually between five to eight minutes.   1321. I purchased Seche Vite because I've heard so many good things about it and it's basically the go-to top coat for any nail enthusiast. However I'm not completely won over. While it's fast drying ability is outstanding, I can't get over the shrinkage effect. It makes your coat of nail polish shrink to create a visible white space with no polish on the tip of the nail. I have heard that this is a side effect of using fast drying top coat over very thickly applied polish but I've tested this by using the Seche Vite over a very thin layer of polish and it still did it. So if you're in a hurry and aren't a perfectionist then this is definitely a really great top coat to use. But I just can't stand the shrinkage!

  1344. I love painting my nails almost to the point of obsession. I hate going to salons because their manicures actually chip faster than the ones I do myself. While my polish is drying, I'll often look online at other nail polishes to try to plan my next mani. I've read so much about Seche Vite on various nail blogs and I knew I had to try it. I did not notice any chipping, peeling, shrinking, or anything other than quick-drying CRAZYSHINE on the pinky nail, while my other nails continued degrading as usual.<br /><br />Anyway I decided to do a fresh mani with Brucci Gianna's Rockin' Blue. I put 2 coats of the color over some generic dollar store clear coat, and I got distracted for a few minutes so I did not apply the Seche Vite to fresh, wet nails. They were sort of tacky I guess by the time I put the top coat on so they weren't exactly wet or dry. I put two coats of the Seche on and my nails seemed instantly dry, I thought it was too good to be true, but after five or ten minutes I was able to rummage through my purse, pick eye goops out of my dog's eyes, and then wash my hands (because eww, eye goops). Then my friends wanted to go out for late night munchies and I was able to function without screwing up my nails. No nicks, no bumps, no smudges, no bubbles. Totally awesome.   1367. Seche Vite is by far THE BEST top coat I’ve ever used. I manicure my nails at home and use the Seche Vite top coat and Seche Clear base coat with a variety of nail polish brands like Essie, OPI, Orly and even Sally Hansen - all with fabulous, long-lasting results.<br /><br />I used to dedicate about 3 hours every 3 days to maintain my OPI base and top coat manicure, and more time with other brands. I was so frustrated that I bought a UV lamp and started doing gel color to get a longer-lasting manicure. The process destroyed my nails after a few weeks and it was super expensive. Now, I only spend about an hour once a week (give or take a few days) and they always look great! And, it adds a layer of strength to my nails that I’ve only ever gotten from a gel manicure.<br /><br />The Seche Vite top coat is made to work with the Seche Clear base coat - they create a bond with the color in between. I apply a thin coat of the base, wait a few minutes so it is still a bit tacky, then put on 1-2 coats of color. After the color has set, but not dried completely, I apply Seche Vite. The top coat firms up almost immediately so I don’t have to worry about messing it up with light activity, and after 20-30 minutes, I continue with my normal activities.<br /><br />I’ve tried the top coat without the base coat and though it still looks great, I’m convinced the base+top coat combo is the key. My manicures last around 7-10 days, and even come out unscathed after scrubbing a bathroom or digging in the dirt. And, if the color starts to look dull, I apply another top coat to shine it up.<br /><br />It does have a strong odor because it does contain toluene, so make sure you aren’t using these in a tiny, enclosed space. The good thing is, the smell doesn’t linger. Also, as you get down to the lower half of the bottle, it becomes thicker - it’s still usable and I get the same results, but I have purchased the refill size to top it off and maintain the consistency for easier application.<br /><br />I’ve also included a photo of my nails after day 8. You can see a little flaking on the side of my middle and index fingers, and the color (Essie Mojito Madness) is a little dull, but still looks good!r /><br />I’ve also included a photo of my nails after day 8. You can see a little flaking on the side of my middle and index fingers, and the color (Essie Mojito Madness) is a little dull, but still looks good!
  1368. I LOVE this top coat! My new favorite. When i'm in a rush but need to paint my nails, this helps them to dry very fast to where I can grab things without my nails smudging. If you are looking for a top coat that prevents your polish from chipping or peeling off than this isn't for you because I find that my nail polish does still chip and peel, but hey, the price is good.
  1369. Love love love this top coat! Dries super fast. The only negative is that it will smear your matte polishes .

  1374. Best top coat in the world!!! I HIGHLY recommend this polish, has amazing shine and dries super fast!

  1376. I don't normally listen to reviews on products of any kind to make a decision but based on the fact that there are a million and one different quick dry top coats I thought it wise to do a little research before shelling out however much money my chosen TC would be and Seche Vite always seemed to be the top runner in top coats. So after some time I finally got a bottle of it and I absolutely loved it at first, the shine is gorgeous and the drying time is fantastic especially when you are painting your nails while your 15 month old takes a nap. But after several destroyed manicures later I am fed up and I decided I hate Seche Vite. It has some good qualities yes but My nails ALWAYS chip the same day heck I have had them chip a couple hours after painting them and its not like I am re-grouting my bathroom to get chips like that on a fresh manicure and I always get major shrinkage. This product may work for some, but I am starting to see so many unsatisfied people. I say forgo the Seche Vite and invest in some good old Sally Hansen quick dry topcoat or the Diamond shine topcoat it works really well too it may not dry as fast but its pretty dang quick. Plus both of those choices will make much less of a dent in your wallet.
  1377. Excellent top coat to give your nails that professional look and keep them looking good.
  1378. After I found this top coat, I will never buy another top coat again. This top coat is AMAZING. Even so, I broke it down into a pros and cons list:<br /><br />PROS -<br />-Extremely fast drying, fastest I've ever seen, left hand would be dry by the time I'm done with right hand.<br />-Extremely shiny/polished look, won't ever be dull<br />-Can use for a really long time (especially if you combine it with Seche Restore)<br />-Long lasting, won't chip especially if you use in combination with high quality nail polishes<br /><br />CONS -<br />-Sometimes a thick coat, but it's not too big of a deal since when it dries you can't tell it's thick at all<br />-Dries up quickly if you keep the cap off for too long, hence becoming thick, and leaving a thick coat (again not a problem if you use Seche Restore)<br /><br />I definitely recommend to buy!! It's definitely worth it for the price. Besides, a whole bottle lasts me for 9-12 months, and I change my polishes a LOT!

  1390. A wise woman once said, &#34;A woman is only helpless while she waits for her nail polish to dry.&#34;<br /><br />Well, between you and me, I don't like to be helpless...EVER. It's because of this that I decided to look into a top coat that could dry my nails in less than 5 minutes. That's when I came across Seche Vite. I researched this top coat extensively before I decided to go ahead and purchase it. I was so excited when it arrived, but unfortunately, I was quite disappointed in the results.<br /><br />Seche Vite leaves a beautiful, mirror-like gloss on top of your nails, which is absolutely fabulous, and it DOES dry your nails within 5 minutes or less. HOWEVER, the product states that it will &#34;absolutely not chip.&#34; Okay, so, to be technical, they weren't lying. Seche Vite will NOT chip, but it will PEEL like a friggin' banana. While I love the way that it makes my nails look, it's useless when the top coat peels off (along with the nail polish underneath) over the course of the day.<br /><br />I would NOT recommend this product unless you're only looking for a beautiful, glossy look for an hour---and even then, there are no guarantees.

  1401. I'm on my third bottle of SV now, and it is definitely the fastest drying topcoat out there. Within seconds, your nails are okay to touch lightly and within an hour they're solid. On the other hand, I've never been able to finish a bottle of SV - a quarter of the way into the bottle, the polish begins turning gummy, and by the half bottle mark, it's more like spreading gluey paste onto my nails than painting with polish. I always end up throwing half the bottle away. Plus the smell is AWFUL and there is definitely a shrinkage issue with this polish.<br /><br />I used to love this for the fast dry time, but ultimately I don't think it outweighs the cons.   1405. My daughters and I have been using this for years. It really works.
  1406. I've used so many different top coats and I always come back to SV. It self-levels into a glassy, shiny, perfectly smooth layer every time. It can smooth out textured glitter, nail art and rhinestones. It dries to the touch in one minute and it completely hard in less than 10 minutes. I've never found a top coat that dries faster than that. I can paint my nails before bed, add a coat of SV, and my nails are dry before I drift off to sleep and I don't wake up with sheet marks or smudges!! The only downside is that it sometimes reacts weird with certain polishes resulting in what is known as &#34;shrinkage.&#34; I've never had much problem with shrinkage but many people have. The only time I've noticed it is with chunky glitter polishes. The other problem with it is that if you shower in hot water, it sometimes reacts weird to it and the polish peels off in whole sheets. You just have to be careful not to pick at your nails in the shower or right after. It goes back to its normal hardness after about 20 minutes of being out of the shower. I've just gotten used to it so it doesn't bother me anymore. Its even convenient that you can just peel your polish off in the shower if you were planning on removing your polish anyway. Also if you're a &#34;picker&#34; like me and enjoying peeling it off. But the first time it happens, it can be frustrating. But it only effects certain polishes. The smell takes some getting used to. I've found some people can't stand it and some people don't mind it. Its a very strong chemical smell. I don't mind it but my roommate in college hated the smell. I'm sure the chemicals in it will probably effect me in the long run since I've been using it for 3 years, but I don't really care. I've bought so many bottles of this stuff I've lost track. This is THE only top coat in my opinion. I would recommend to anyone.
  1407. For once, my reading comments has paid off. This is the best top coat I have ever used! It provides a brilliant shine and literally protects your nail polish. My polished nails last about 5-7 days with this top coat. When I used Orly Won't Chip I would get about 2-4 days of wear, if I was lucky. This also dries your nails in about 3 minutes if you use a UV lamp. Worth every penny.

  1412. I read all the reviews about Seche Vite before I ordered and used it, so I was well-prepared for shrinkage, peeling, and strong odor. I applied the Seche Vite while my nail polish was still wet and found it absolutely EASY to apply. It seems thick going on but dries flawlessly smooth and brilliantly shiny. It dries my manicure so quickly that I am able to get back to work immediately -- yes, immediately. I run a small farm with organic garden and free-range chickens, so I don't have time to sit around waiting for polish to dry. In fact, you'd think that nail polish would be a frivolous luxury for someone in my line of work. Indeed, it would be but for SECHE VITE! I can have great-looking nails and still spend entire days outdoors with my hands in the dirt. Thank you Seche Vite, you have changed my life. P.S. Not one bit of excess shrinkage or peeling, but yes, the odor is strong and does linger.<br /><br />Want also to comment on some of the \\"cons\\" several reviewers mentioned. PEELING: it doesn't peel at all. If someone is having a problem with peeling, they're doing something wrong. EXCESSIVE SHRINKING: it does shrink a little, so you have to take precautions. That said, a little shrinking can be anticipated and planned for.<br /><br />ONE GREAT HINT: Use China Glaze Strong Adhesion Base Coat as your first coat on clean nails. Follow with your color polish. Then paint on ANOTHER coat of China Glaze Strong Adhesion Base Coat followed immediately by the Seche Vite. You will get the greatest, most long-lasting manicure EVER!

  1431. I did some research and found that this top coat has some of the highest reviews, and I can see why! It dries super fast and leaves a very shiny/glossy finish (if you don't like super shiny, don't get this). It saves a lot of time that I would be wasting sitting around waiting for my nail polish to dry. The only downside that I've found is that although it dries extremely quickly, if you have multiple layers of polish underneath, those layers do not dry. Seche vite just puts a protective coating above it all, but it still takes time for the bottom layers to solidify (so if you were to push down on your nail after you put on Seche Vite, not polish would come off, but there would be a dent). I still gave this top coat 5 stars since I don't believe it promises drying the bottom layers, just the top, and it does a great job of that.

  1441. Good topcoat and definitely lives up to its claim of fast drying. Even over thick layers of nail polish color, this dries in minutes and I can be completely functional and go about my business in about 15-20 minutes. You can even go to sleep without worrying about sheet marks. Works great on pedicures during the winter too, you can slip your feet into shoes without worrying about smudging your toes.<br /><br />The shine and finish is excellent, glossy and beautiful. My only gripe is the lasting power, it seems to shrink the polish a bit and I usually get chips at the tips around day 2 or 3. But that's a characteristic that most fast dry top coats have, so I'm not complaining too much. A must have for those who like to change nail polish often.
  1442. Seche is a cult classic in the nail world, so I was excited to try it. I generally use higher end polishes like Butter London, OPI, China Glaze, Zoya, and others, but have a busy schedule that makes doing my nails a trial without quickdry topcoat. As a result, I've tried many on the market. I'd place Seche Vite in the upper middle end compared to others I have used. For me, the cons outweigh its pros, so it is not my go-to topcoat.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Dries very quickly - its definitely faster than other topcoats on the market. I however do think that this is a double edged sword and is likely a contributor to the drawbacks I experienced.<br />- Has a high glass shine. This shine lasts as long as the topcoat does, which is definitely a plus.<br />- Can be found for a reasonable price if you know where to look - online and small shops tend to be much more realistic than major retailers.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- The shrinkage is awful. The topcoat's underwear seems to matter very little in the outcome here. Nothing feels worse than topping a flawless application and having it look cracked and sloppy because of the topcoat.<br />- Cracks often are visible in a couple of days. While this is unnoticable on dark colours, it can really detract from a light or bright colour.<br />- I've had only a couple of instances where use of this topcoat has not resulted in significant peeling. This frequent peeling makes subsequent chips large and very difficult to repair. By a couple of days in, I've had half of a nail peeling off, usually more than one. This is much worse on my flatter nails.<br />- This is an extremely smelly topcoat.<br />- Personally, I think that when I purchase a product that I should be able to get full use of it without the requirement of purchasing an additional product. Before reaching even halfway into the bottle, you are likely to encounter a goopy, stringy mess that you can barely get on to the brush. The fact that one must purchase Seche's proprietary thinner to be able to get anywhere close to finishing a bottle is a bit deceptive and frustrating.<br />- Application can be difficult to master, but is definitely possible. Throw your ideas about thin coats out the window with this one, and you're okay. Because of how fast it dries, you really have to get it right - do-overs or fix-ups are very difficult.<br />- I found that Seche has a higher tendency to lift polish than others I have tried, even with proper application. This was surely unnoticable to anyone but myself, but I did find that it sometimes resulted in streaking as well.<br />- I have noticed a difference in the general condition of my nails using this product over other quick-dry topcoats, even with all other practices remaining the same. They seem to get dry and peel more easily when I use this regularly.<br /><br />Overall, I see why people like it. If I were to only plan on wearing a manicure for one day, such as for a special occasion, this polish's drawbacks would be more of a non-issue. However, I do want to see longer wear with better presentation. As much as I can appreciate a topcoat that dries as quickly and glossy as Seche, I would rather wait a bit longer or even use two coats of a formula that works better for me.<br /><br />One thing that is clear is that one's nail structure and products used with Seche can play a big role in how well it will work for you - it's definitely worth a try!e's proprietary thinner to be able to get anywhere close to finishing a bottle is a bit deceptive and frustrating.<br />- Application can be difficult to master, but is definitely possible. Throw your ideas about thin coats out the window with this one, and you're okay. Because of how fast it dries, you really have to get it right - do-overs or fix-ups are very difficult.<br />- I found that Seche has a higher tendency to lift polish than others I have tried, even with proper application. This was surely unnoticable to anyone but myself, but I did find that it sometimes resulted in streaking as well.<br />- I have noticed a difference in the general condition of my nails using this product over other quick-dry topcoats, even with all other practices remaining the same. They seem to get dry and peel more easily when I use this regularly.<br /><br />Overall, I see why people like it. If I were to only plan on wearing a manicure for one day, such as for a special occasion, this polish's drawbacks would be more of a non-issue. However, I do want to see longer wear with better presentation. As much as I can appreciate a topcoat that dries as quickly and glossy as Seche, I would rather wait a bit longer or even use two coats of a formula that works better for me.<br /><br />One thing that is clear is that one's nail structure and products used with Seche can play a big role in how well it will work for you - it's definitely worth a try!

I even put it to the test by putting on two coats of China Glaze polish and a thick coat of the Seche Vite last night about 40 mins before bed and woke up this morning without sheet marks! Then, on top of that this morning, I stamped a design on top of the Seche Vite with White On by Sally Hansen then put on another coat of the Seche Vite. They are absolutely glass-like!! I'm extremely impressed with this top coat and will be recommending it to everyone I know.<br /><br />Update: While everything I wrote above remains true, I've encountered a problem. MAJOR shrinkage. For some reason, as this topcoat dries, it shrinks my nail polish. It causes it to crack along the edges, which leads to chips within two days. Such a disappointment!!
