  1522. I've used Seche Vite for a long time, but I always resist buying ANOTHER bottle when I start getting low, because this stuff makes my polish chip like nothing I've ever seen. It's really pretty before the shine dulls (3-4 days), and it DOES dry my nails super-fast, but I'd prefer my nail polish not chip between manis (every week). The reason it makes your polish chip is that something weird in the formula makes every layer of polish on your nail kind of 'melt' together into just one layer. If you ding your nailtip, a single layer will chip off much easier than layer over layer over layer. I might give away the bottle I have right now because it irritates me so much. This product would be perfect if it didn't also contribute to polish-chipping.
  1523. I recently started getting fancy with my nails. I purchased a nail stamping kit, stamping plates, dotting tools, rhinestones, nail glue, 500 fake nails, and a BUNCH of new nail polish. Some of the nail polish didn't dry very nicely, looking matte instead of shiny. Nearly all of the nail polish I purchased was less than $1.50 a bottle, so it was by no means high quality. However, I am just not willing to spend more than a couple dollars for a bottle of nail polish, especially when you buy so many different colors. It adds up! At first, I was reluctant to purchase Seche Vite Dry Fast Top Coat because I really didn't want to spend $5 for one bottle. I was previously using Sally Hansen, and I am not even sure if it was a top coat or a clear nail polish. Either way, it did not look good. Maybe it was old, but the color of the liquid actually looked a little yellowed. It also would make my nail polish bleed; I would see my nail polish color on the brush no matter how long I let the polish dry before applying the top coat. I am so glad I found this on Amazon and gave in and bought it. It is absolutely worth it.. Seche Vite dries extremely quickly, and SO shiny; I actually thought my nails were still wet because of the shine, and was shocked that it had dried THAT shiny. Seche Vite makes your nails look beautifully glassy, and helps to hide any imperfections. I also applied a couple of coats of Seche Vite under my nail polish, where my nail had torn about 1/4 way across. The tear was quite far down, and would have been painful to remove. This helped keep my nail from ripping the rest of the way off until I could find my nail glue. I also used Seche Vite to stick and seal on rhinestones, using one coat to stick the rhinestone on, and a second coat over the nail and rhinestone to keep it on. It worked great, since it made it stick without clouding the rhinestone, or leave any residue like glue could have. I really love this top coat and wonder how I ever did my nails without it! People who do nail art should definitely invest in this item so your art can last longer and look professional without the cost!d my nails without it! People who do nail art should definitely invest in this item so your art can last longer and look professional without the cost!

  1550. I was on the hunt for a great topcoat that would help my polish stay on my nails as my polish tends to chip off the same day I apply it. I have never had polish last for longer than a day and a half on my nails even with a good base coat and roughing them up and all that.<br /><br />I purchased both Seche Vite (SV) and Deborah Lippman Addicted To Speed (DL ATS) topcoat. DL ATS cost $20 for a bottle, SV cost $5. I used the same amount of coats of a China Glaze polish on both hands and I put SV on one and DL ATS on the other.<br /><br />The hand with Seche Vite had a blindingly bright shine, dried very fast and lasted for 3 days before chipping/peeling off my nails.<br /><br />The hand with DL ATS topcoat had a nice subtle shine, dried just as quickly and the polish lasted 2 1/2 days before chipping lightly.<br /><br />So the very expensive topcoat lasted slightly less but didn't chip nearly as much, but both were great products. I was a bit surprised that the Seche Vite nails peeled like they did. The way it peeled up, I just tugged and watched my polish come off in one whole piece.<br /><br />In the end I was very pleasantly surprised with Seche Vite. For $5 a bottle, it lasted longer the high end stuff, the shine was gorgeous and the application wasn't as difficult as some said it would be. I didn't think the high end stuff was good enough to spend $15 more a bottle. I'll be sticking with Seche Vite.<br /><br />Caveat: If you are the type of person who likes to fill in the chips and reapply the topcoat, this one is not a winner. I found the topcoat sort of -resistant- to repairs. Since I don't tend to repair my polish because I'm fickle and get bored with color quickly, this wasn't a problem for me.

  1566. My first couple of tries with Seche Vite...I wasn't lovin' it. With other top coats, I usually wait a few minutes after the 2nd coat of color to apply (cos I don't like when the color's still wet and taints the top coat in the bottle).<br /><br />So, my first time using SV top coat, I waited about 10 minutes before applying it. My polish began chipping off within 24 hours.<br />My 2nd attempt, I applied the base coat and 2 coats of color to all 10 nails, and then immediately applied the SV. Polish came off in chunks yet again.<br />Third attempt, I applied the base coat and one coating of color too all 10 nails, then 2nd coating of color, only to my left hand, and immediately followed that with SV. I then applied the 2nd coating of color on my right hand and quickly followed with SV. Muuuuuuch better results! Seems the wetter the polish, the better this stuff works. So, yeah, I'm a fan now. OH! And, don't get me started on the drying time! This is the fastest drying top coat I've ever had the pleasure of using. Amazing! Within two minutes, you can run your fingers over your nails with no damage to your manicure. In about 10-15 minutes (heck, maybe even less), your manicure is completely dry.<br /><br />I've deducted one star because I can't use it with my crackle polish or Konad Stamping Nail Art kit. The crackle needs a couple of minutes to, well, crack up & your polish has to dry before you can use the Konad stamp thingie. Therefore, you can't immediately follow with a top coat. I'll continue to use my Jordana Quick Shine top coat for that.
  1567. I was so happy to receive the Seche Vite Dry Fast Top Coat in the mail and esp since I paid less than $11 for two. I immediately used the top with Zoya nail polish. And yes, my nails dried very fast. No smudging, no marks. A day later, I noticed peeling on a couple of nails. Then slight chipping on others. I was told I may have an old polish. Which sucks. I ordered one for me and one for a friend and she said her polish chipped fast also. I gave two stars because my nails did dry fast.

  1569. Now I haven't tried any OPI top coats, heard they do well, but they are even more expensive, so I didn't try it yet. Seche Vite is the best top coat, it's fast, it leaves an incredible shine and it last long through all hand washing, showers, dish washing you name it. It makes the nails look like you put in a lot of work, when it maybe takes five good minutes, just to make sure it's completely dry.<br /><br />I have painted my nails before with another top coat, went to sleep thinking it was dry, wake up, and the polish is smudged and indented with the sheet print, very frustrating. With Seche Vite, I could paint, go into my purse, go to bed, take a shower shortly after, and the polish is solidly in place. Also, Sally' Beauty usually has a deal, so check it out, it's good stuff.

While I'll continue to use this over my regular manicures, since I change polish so often, I don't think I'll use this over any of my more intricate manicures or any that I'd like to last more than 3-4 days. Edited 3/4/15 to add the following: The price for three bottles is a great deal. I have a love/hate with Seche Vite. The shine and the quickness with which it dries are amazing...the shrinkage still annoys me. I advise investing in a bottle of Seche Restore to thin it when it thickens...and it WILL thicken. The Restore will last a very long time, as it only takes a drop or two to do the trick.

  1729. I was expecting the Holy Grail of all top coats. This was not it, however good it was. The reason it only has 3 stars is because of all of the cons. For one, while it dried to the touch in mere moments, it was still extremely easy to smudge it and push the polish around. The brush picked up color and deposited it into the bottle, and it discolored my manicures, especially my white ones. It also lead to a crazy amount of peeling. To be fair, I've always had a peeling problem with my polish, never having had a manicure last less than a day. The coat itself was hard to apply at the correct time due to the requirement of it being applied on semi-wet polish. It smeared my nail art like crazy if I applied too early, and picked up even more polish when applied to lat. For all of its faults though, this top coat had a lot going for it. It made my manicures dry to the touch in minutes, and added a crazy amount of shine. I had very high hopes for this though, even being exceptionally cautious and thorough, but it didn't live up to the hype. All the same, this is the best top coat I've found to date.
  1730. Best top coat I've tried. The issue is the one I received was clearly used.
  1731. i didn't check whether or not this polish was three free (no toluene, dibutyl phthalate, and formaldehyde) or not when i purchased it; i was simply going by the reviews of my peers, who said that this was their very favorite topcoat.<br /><br />so i was a bit disappointed to find it's got toluene in it - a product that is used typically as a solvent and can dissolve things like paint, paint thinners, rubber, printing ink, etc. and is water-insoluble. nail polish's stereotypical paint thinner smell is due partially to this chemical, which is why three free polishes don't smell as bad.<br /><br />so, friendly tip: try not to get any on your skin or breathe too much of the stench. not good for you.<br /><br />but it is A VERY GOOD TOPCOAT nonetheless. just took polish remover to the polish i applied the day it arrived, which was a week and a half ago. the polish had JUST started chipping. probably has to do with toluene's water-resistant properties.<br /><br />TL;DR: very good polish, not very good for you.

  1786. The reviews on this were crazy! It seems that there's a cult for this top coat. I do like it, and it does what it says it will - it dries quickly and protects the base color. And sometimes, if my color could use some shine, Seche Vite doesn't really help too much. But for the price, it's really a good buy. One bottle has a lot of product, too, and the brush is really nice at spreading (though sometimes too much polish gets on there). Overall, pretty good, just not life-changing.

I advise anyone To just go to a local ulta and pick it up, this one was fake.   1807. I have been reading about this brand of topcoat for so long now. I do not know why I never bought it until recently. I think maybe the price had something to do with it. After all I thought it was just clear nail polish and I can get that at the dollar store.<br /> Am I glad that I finally took the plunge and bought a bottle.<br /> I am not what they call someone who spends a lot of time on &#34;cuticle care&#34; (Pitch Perfect reference *high5*) I keep my nail shorts because they tend to chip & break easily if I do not. I love nail polish colors, God knows I have plenty of them.<br /> Just recently I got my first &#34;gel mani&#34;, boy, was I ever impressed. It was awesome. The color I chose was a beautiful green color that resembled something you'd see on a tropical island, it was so shiny and strong. I went swimming, playing in the sand, playing in the ocean, doing all kinds of outdoorsy stuff on my vacation, and not one chip was to be seen.<br /> In fact it was not until the 12th or 13th day that I noticed the color was coming off from the bottom up, noticed the top down. Which is what I like.<br /><br />Back to SECHE VITE DRY FAST TOP COAT: when I am not doing a gel manicure (which is always) I like my normal polish manicure (with a little bit of nail art on ring fingers to make me feel pretty) to last as long as humanly possible.<br /> Not only does this topcoat make my polish last days longer, it also makes my nails incredibly shiny, and it is helping them to grow stronger and longer.<br /> I am using a vitamin filled base coat to help my nails grow strong (Orly), I use a coat of this on top of the base coat, then I put my color , then I use this as my topcoat/quick dry, and I let it dry for about 20 minutes before I do anything.<br /><br /> I have found that quick dry topcoats, quick dry sprays and drops, etc. Are not really quick dry at all. In fact when you try to use your nails too quickly after applying the quick dry topcoat, you will find smudges/ridges, and your nails become messy. I believe it helps the polish to dry a couple of minutes faster, but not immediately. The quick dry labeling lulls you into a false sense of security. I am sure many of us out there have used a quick dry product only to end up having to redo our nails.<br /><br /> To wrap it up I think that this product is outstanding. I can see what all of the hype is about, and I'm still not sure whether it is worth the price, but I believe it is money well spent, for me anyways.<br /> I found that this product has done what it says it will do. Except for the quick dry thing. I believe it dries nails quicker, but not the quickest. Or completely.<br /><br /> I like using this polish on top of my base coat. There are times when I want to go polish free, but I like to use the vitamin enriched base coat to strengthen and lengthen my brittle nails. This topcoat not only enhances the vitamin base coat it also adds a beautiful shine.s, and your nails become messy. I believe it helps the polish to dry a couple of minutes faster, but not immediately. The quick dry labeling lulls you into a false sense of security. I am sure many of us out there have used a quick dry product only to end up having to redo our nails.<br /><br /> To wrap it up I think that this product is outstanding. This is awful, I tried this on my manicure and it would peel off in sheets, I have since then put on acrylics, I figured I would try this again, I figured anything can stick to the acrylics, it came off in sheets once again! I don't get the rave reviews on how wonderful it is. I am a cashier and work in food service with powdered disposable gloves and this stuff comes off with the gloves. So...I thought one more try because I really wanted to like it and applied it in thin coats. The same thing happened, I'm done, tried everything with no results. Avon UV top coat holds up well as well as OPI top coat, not this seche vite
  1910. i recommend this top coat. not expensive and it works really great. it makes your nails dry faster last longer and look super shiny
  1911. This product does exactly as it says it will, it dries fast. I notice a big difference when I do my nails it cuts the amount of time needed to dry down to minimal!!
  1912. I've tried this Seche Vite fast dry topcoat with polishes from a variety of manufacturers, some higher end and some less so (including, but not limited to Sheswai, Zoya, OPI, Seche Vite, and Revlon). My average time prior to chipping is about 2 days; Zoya polish lasted a bit longer. However, chips are pretty minor and I am very hard on my hands throughout the day.<br /><br />I have not had any problems with any of the above-listed brands in combination with this top coat. Some of those brands are &#34;3 free&#34; (3 referring to dibutyl phthalate, toluene, and formaldehyde) and some aren't. Seche Vite topcoat does contain toluene, by the way. The topcoat does have an odor and I know the odor is from toluene (I worked with toluene sometimes while in the lab in grad school). However, I find that the odor dissipates quickly.<br /><br />I do not get any peeling or shrinkage with this topcoat and it dries quickly and with a nice shine. I also think it helps to dry the polish under the topcoat; the Revlon polish I used recently was kind of thick and took a long time to dry between coats. I got impatient and put the Seche Vite topcoat on it while it was still a little wet. This seemed to make the polish underneath dry faster.<br /><br />So, in the end, I find that this dries quickly, looks nice, and works with a variety of polishes (both those that are &#34;3 free&#34; and those that are not). This product page contains reviews written over a period of several years so I will also mention that I bought this in late 2013 and have been using it (same bottle) a couple of times a week for the last two months or so. The performance has been consistent over that period of time.
  1913. It's cheaper than OPI top coat, but I prefer the former. Seche Vite worked fine, but it was a thicker formula. I think the OPI top coat is slightly easier to work with. It's a matter of preference, I guess. The OPI top coat also lasts longer for me. With the SV, my polish began chipping sooner.

It made a huge mess and was embarrassing. I am frustrated that I cannot return this product as it was definitely not worth the money. A bottle of top coat from the 99 cent store does a better job.
  1917. I wanna start out by saying this is by far the best topcoat I have ever set my sights on! It is SOOOO SHINY and dries at lightning speed! Now the reason I gave this 4 stars is because it does contain toulene (google it) which is linked to numerous health problems. Also when approaching the half bottle mark it begins to get VERY clumpy. When you pull the brush out of the bottle it brings with it little strings of the polish! That being said the problem can easily be fixed by adding a few drops of seche restore! If you are going to buy the topcoat, seche restore is a MUST HAVE. So overall this is a great topcoat! Try to limit use (because of the toulene), and also buy seche restore!

It's super shiny, actually does dry fast, and lasts a long time. Before getting this, the longest my nail polish would last me without chipping would probably be 5 days. With this, I've gone for over 2 weeks without a chip, where I only take it off because my nails have grown out.   1974. I was so fed up with my nails breaking ALL the time. I did some research and realized it was due to me using neither top or base coats. After a lot of research I finally decided on this product. It's clear and goes on really smooth. However there are some issues with it.<br /><br />Sometimes I like to do nail art and paint cute designs. When I put this top coat on it flattened out my work- this can be a good thing and a bad thing. It makes my scraggly lines look straighter but also thicker so I have to put on a very thin amount. It's AMAZING for little rhinestones you definitely don't need glue with this top coat! The finish this gives makes it look like I'm wearing acrylic nails!<br /><br />The downside to this is that if you get it even a little your skin on the edge of your nail and it dries on your skin- when your nail starts to grow out the nail polish on your skin will move with the nail polish on your nail and cause it to peel very easily. So it's not very flexible. If one part of the nail polish peels off it doesn't &#34;break off&#34; so you can fake having nail polish on for some time before it peels off completely.<br /><br />Another thing is that it bonds with all the other nail polish you have on- so if it comes off so does the rest of your nail work.<br /><br />I've had some issues with the nail polish chipping at the tip- I think it has something to do with it bond to the rest of the nail polish and maybe 'shrinking' when it's dry. I've sort of found a solution to this by applying it not only on the nail but under it and making sure it's on the edge on the nail too. I use about 2 coats.<br /><br />Even though it says and seems it's fast drying. Only the surface is the rest of the nail polish is still very much wet so don't do anything for at least 30 -40 minutes unless you want wrinkles in your nails.<br /><br />All in all I love the finish it gives but wish it would stay on longer. Before this my nail polish would stay on for weeks, now it's down toonly 5 days or so. It may also be my new base coat- either way I'm okay with it because it's definitely made my nails a million times stronger without nail polish because of this nail polish.<br /><br />On a positive note it protects- I am a very busy girl and a very creative one at that. Before any scrapes or paint or even showering/washing dishes would cause my nail polish to come off even with dish washing gloves on. With this nail polish it happens no more which is the most important to me.<br /><br />I don't recommend it if your Nail Artist because it won't last and its prone to messing up your work. If you wear FAKE nails I don't recommend it either. But if you want that acrylic look without messing up your nails with glue and your really active or even just an everyday girl who doesn't mind giving herself a mani every week or so it's a must have!
  1975. I recently discovered this product and it is truly amazing. It dries extremely fast and leaves a beautiful glossy shine on the nails. I've used it on top of the cheapest to the most expensive nail polish brands and the effect is the same - simply brilliant. It takes about 5 minutes to dry fully on two thick layers of nail polish.

  2040. There are reviews on here that ask how this top coat has gotten good reviews, but I don't understand how it got any bad reviews. The part I like most is you apply it after the final coat of polish and your nails are dry in minutes, with a high gloss finish. There's no waiting for an hour for color to dry just so you can apply a top coat. My nailcolor lasts until I get bored & change it, with little to no chipping at all (and I do dishes by hand, open cans, etc.). I highly recommend this product!

  2043. If you have trouble with:<br />Dents<br />Fingerprints<br />Bubbles<br />Sheet marks<br />Being impatient and screwing over your manicure right after doing it<br /><br />...then Seche Vite will be a godsend to you. I cycled through so many brands of polish and top coats, always ending up with the same frustrating dents and marks. And yes, I followed all the rules I could find about thin coats, waiting forever between coats, even refrigerating my polishes to reduce bubbling. Even other \\"quick dry\\" top coats would sometimes seal in the still-wet polish underneath and never allow it to fully dry (ending up squishy, kind of like a waterbed. Or like painting acrylic over oil.) No exaggeration here when I say I would sometimes do my nails FIVE HOURS before bed and still end up with sheet marks. I'm not saying I wasn't doing anything wrong, but I sure as hell wasn't able to figure out what it was, try as I might.<br /><br />Finally got Seche Vite. Dry to the touch almost instantly, and fully hardened within minutes. Let me put this is capital letters so that people skimming the reviews will tune in: USE IT OVER TACKY/WET POLISH. There, I said it. Now there's no excuse for you to go home and slop it on over day-old dry polish, or straight on a dry nail bed. If you use it over dry polish, it's much more likely to peel up. Unlike other quick-dry polishes, it won't seal in wet polish in a bad way, not allowing it to fully dry. It will instead penetrate the layers of your wet polish and actually harden them. It's awesome.<br /><br />As for it's durability, I have had varying results depending on what polish I have under it. Right now my nails are about 6 days old, and I have a few noticeable chips at the tips of 3 or 4 fingers. Which is not unreasonable. It certainly doesn't chip any more than the other top coats I've tried, so I have no complaints there.

  2097. OMG! BEST.PRODUCT.EVER. I spent a lot of time researching good top coats & came across Seche Vite. I read the hype but was still skeptical about trying it myself. The reviews all said positive things & it seemed just to good to be true. It was only $4.40 with free shipping so I figured what the heck, I'll give it a go. I CANT IMAGINE LIFE WITHOUT IT. It is the absolute best top coat I've tried. It dries fast. Super fast. And gives a gel-like shine. Exactly what I was looking for. No more smudges & mess ups while waiting for your nails to dry! You can find it at local drug stores (walgreens has it for $10.99) but I'd rather pay less & I only had to wait 4-5 days to use it when I received it. It's great for regular manicures & nail art/nail stamping as well as glitter polishes. I paint my 2 coats of color, wait for about a minute after second coat & apply a thick bead of Seche Vite. (It's best used when polish is wet/still tacky) If you apply too much to the nail, no worries. As it dries it will even itself out giving you a smooth finish. I also found that any imperfections I made with my color coat, Seche Vite smooths & evens out for a flawless manicure every time. It does have a powerful odor so I advise using it in a well ventilated area. Some people complain about the odor but it doesn't bother me at all. If you can go to a nail salon & handle the smell, you'll have no problem with this because it's not even half as bad. Some people have also mentioned that it thickens when you get halfway through the bottle so I'd recommend using Seche Restore which provides the ingredients that have evaporated from the bottle over time to get it back to its original consistency. When I run out I'm buying the larger refill size that is also sold on Amazon. I'm obsessed with it & telling everyone I know about this product! Ladies, it's a must have. This will be the last top coat you ever try!! Buy it now & don't waste time like I did... You won't regret it!

I'll probably never break a nail on a door handle again.<br />Second, the shine is so pretty...<br />Third, it dried pretty darn quick. I didn't time it or anything, but I've never done a paint job with a single base coat, 2 polish coats, and a top coat dried so fast that I was eating pizza 45 minutes later and not a smudge to be found. Awesome!<br />Now this last thing is the reason I didn't give it 5 stars: (and it could be user error, I admit it)but the very tip of my nails, the polish has pulled back on about half of my nails revealing just the tiniest sliver of white that really I can only see close up. I'm not sure if it was my initial coverage not being as thick with the polish colors, the top coat, or perhaps these nails were more dry when I used the top coat. I'll definitely have to practice more and update review later.<br />Very happy overall and will continue to use it even if the very tips keep peeling back, it's just so darn great!
  2132. saw it on a review & loved it, one happy customer great top coat! price is very good aswell !
  2133. it does what i bought it for, very shiny and does not yellow when i smoke, a lot of top coats do.
  2134. Love this product! Dries so quickly and lasts!

  2136. It works very well for me great product
  2137. I used Seche Vite for years because so many people said it was the best. And I thought it was, but only because it dries so fast. It never seemed to prevent my polish from chipping; actually, whatever top coat the Vietnamese ladies use at my cheap neighborhood nail salon is far superior in terms of chipping. It doesn't dry fast, but my manicure lasts at least a week. When I used Seche Vite, I always had chipping by Day 3. And shrinkage is definitely an issue. I recently tried Poshé because I'd seen it mentioned on some blogs and it was cheap at the beauty supply store. It dries even faster than Seche Vite. With Seche Vite, you still need to be careful with your nails for an hour or so, but with Poshé you're good to go in like 10 minutes, 15 at the most. I've only used it twice, but my polish lasted 5 and 6 days without chips. There's some shrinkage, as there will be with any fast-drying top coat, but it isn't as bad as with Seche Vite. I haven't had it long enough to see if it gets all gummy like Seche Vite does, but I figure I'll just use the Seche Vite Restore with it if it does. Seche Vite is good, but I'm glad to have found something better.

  2153. It really does dry fast and it stays looking shiny for days. Most polishes I've tried loose their shine after a day or so. It looks like glass when you apply it, so shiny!!
  2154. UPDATE 3/6/2016: I decided to give this another try because I actually lost my bottle of Sally Hansen Top Coat. I figured out there's a trick to applying it to wet polish. You have to put a LOT of product on the brush. Enough so that it beads at the tip of the brush, and then you GENTLY pull it down the middle of your nail. You do not want the brush to make contact with your polish. The product should be goopy enough to make a sort of barrier between the brush and your nail so your design doesn't smear. Try to finish the nail off in 3 strokes, one down the middle, and one down either side. It will level itself out. Try to keep it off your cuticle and skin because it shrinks as it dries and will peel back from your skin and makes the nail more prone to peeling prematurely. This time around I was able to apply a good coat except for one nail that had an excess amount of Seche Vite pool in one corner and as it dried, it wrinkled up. But the rest of my nails turned out good. I have to go to work in an hour and we'll see if it can withstand 6 hours of hard labor. EDIT #2: I'm pleasantly surprised. Glad I gave this top coat another try. It was a busy day at work. Scrubbing countertops with chemical cleaners, stocking the cooler, counting change in the registers, and not a single chip or dent in my nails. I let them dry for 2 and a half hours before going to work. I haven't noticed any shrinkage however I don't see an advantage to painting wet polish over dry polish. I would rather let my polish dry to avoid accidentally smearing the design, and you have less shrinkage. I feel comfortable upgrading my rating to 4 stars. The picture attached is after I came home from work. OLD REVIEW: Probably the worst top coat I've used. The directions say you have to apply it to wet nail polish. I was using Sally Hansen's Xtreme polish which is tacky dry in less than 30 seconds so the first time around, I was applying it to mostly dry polish. The top coat was peeling off within a couplehours. The next time I tried it, with a different nail polish, I alternated between applying color and this top coat. So I was applying it on very wet polish. Can you guess what happened? The brush pulled the colored polish right off my nail, unbeknownst to me, and tainted the entire bottle when I dipped the brush back in for more. There are now streaks of colored nail polish inside my Seche Vite bottle. So it doesn't work on dry nails and it definitely does NOT work on wet nails! What a huge fail and waste of money. If you're looking for an alternative, buy Sally Hansen's Dries Instantly top coat. After Seche Vite, I tried OPI and it was equally as terrible. Sally Hansen gives you the shiny mirror-like look you want, smooths out nail ridges, and doesn't drag polish designs. And it was a quarter of the price of Seche Vite.
  2155. Makes your nails soo shiny and they dry so much more quickly! I definitely recommend this product for anyone that wants pretty nails
  2156. I always wondered what to do after spending a long time painting my nails only to have them chip days later. A friend told me about this stuff, and I was not disappointed. It goes on smooth, drys quickly and keeps your polish looking new for twice or triple the time. The only drawback is the smell. It's very strong. But honestly, after it dries, and I wash my hands the smell starts to fade. And it's so worth it!
  2157. I have no idea how other people are having so many problems with this top coat. I've had nothing but excellent results! In fact, when it comes time to change polish, I have to SCRUB this stuff off. My polish doesn't chip hardly at all and I leave my nail polish on for a week or so. I'm not easy on my polish either - I have kids and an OCD clean house, so I'm constantly washing my hands and cleaning, playing around with the kids, etc. It dries super quickly and contrary to what the number one critical reviewer claims, I've used this as a \\"touch up\\" to bring shine back to my polish and had no issues whatsoever. It does have an odor but I use it in a ventilated area (as you should do with any polish anyways) and I don't have problems with it. I don't like that it contains toulene but until there is another top coat that is in any way comparable to this one, I'll continue to use it.

  2159. I started looking for this product after seeing it many times in YouTube videos containing nail art. It really does live up to its claims of drying instantly.   2218. This top coat is literally the best thing that has ever to my life. I normally don't leave reviews but for this I had to.<br /><br />For the longest time I've been trying to find a top coat that worked well and dried fast. I've tried Sally Hansen products, Out the Door Top Coat, all of these, and none of them compare. With Seche Vite my nails literally dry in a minute, and within 15 minutes I can do the dishes, vacuum, run my fingers through my hair, etc. And no sheet marks at all! I'm totally guilty of always wanting to paint my nails right before bed and then I wake up and they're ruined. Seche Vite literally made them stay glossy and they looked perfect in the morning. Seriously, it's worth the money. The smell really isn't any worse than nail polish remover smell and I'm sure the bottle gets thick over time but it's kind of worth it. I always believe in spending more money for higher quality beauty products. It's just worth it to me.<br /><br />NOTE: The nail polish bottle itself is VERY FRAGILE. I bought my first bottle of Seche Vite at Target and painted my nails only once with it. They looked great, super stoked, right? I was going on a trip that weekend and put the bottle in my bag to take with me. I dropped the bag on the floor, and I don't know if it's just me or what, but it shattered and spilled everywhere. I was pretty devastated. So just be careful when traveling with it. Other than that, still worth it, as I went on Amazon and bought another brand new bottle because I couldn't resist. Other than that, I honestly really found nothing wrong with this top coat.
  2219. This is a wonderful topcoat. So far this is probably my favorite of all the brands I've tried but there are a few pros and cons as with most things.<br /><br />This stuff dries fairly quickly, but isn't INSTANT. You still have to wait a bit before touching your nails to anything but the wait time for me has been drastically reduced. One issue I've noticed is if I apply too much color polish and then try to topcoat with this I sometimes get little &#34;waves&#34; in my work if I accidentally touch something because the top of the layer of paint will dry quick, but the bottom will still be wet. I wouldn't recommend hopping into bed immediately after a mani or pedi for this reason. Your sheets will leave all kinds of funky designs behind in the morning.<br /><br />The edges will shrink in with this top coat. I like the outsides around my nailbeds to be clear of polish anyways so this isn't a huge deal for me, but if you don't get close enough to the sides and top of your nail it could look funky, so take this into consideration when painting and don't be afraid to get a bit closer than usual.<br /><br />The last thing to be wary of is that when you put this stuff on it doesn't always look even and the bottle can dry out faster than other products. Sometimes it looks downright weird and gloopy when I put it on. The first time I used it I had a little freak out because I thought I ruined my mani I had just worked hard on, but fear not! When this stuff dries it is beautiful and all the weird glooping and uneveness evens out.<br /><br />All of these nit-picky things aside I really like this product. The top coat is solid and leaves a beautiful finish to my nails. If I'm in a hurry and my nails look nice and clean I'll even throw this on alone because I think the finish is so nice and have cute, glossy nails. The gloss isn't overbearing, and it isnt underwhelming, for me it is just right!

  2229. , I have used this product for awhile on others and on rare occasion myself. As others have stated, it does dry fast and in under 5 minutes. I have noticed that different nail polish brands used underneath it can really affect the chipping and peeling of it. Some polishes (often cheaper ones) often will flake or peel off the next day while others I have used have stayed virtually chipless for more than a week. On toes it can last two weeks. However, it contains toluene as well as formaldehyde which both are toxic. Despite the pros, I'd rather not expose myself or others to these chemicals and have discontinued its use.   2251. Let me tell you something, if you weare this top coat, your polish is going to last for AGES!!! This really is one of the better top coats out there if your number one criteria is staying power. It also has the virtue of being very quick drying.<br /><br />However, if you have nails that tend to be unhealthy like I do (thin, cracks easily, etc.), you may want to look at a different top coat, either that, or alternate this top coat with a different one (which is what I do). The reason being that it is such a good coating that no oxygen gets through AT ALL (either that or it's just laden with nasty chemicals), and after a few weeks of wearing it your nails will start peeling like crazy unless you give them a vacation from this top coat. I have discovered that if I alternate two weeks on, two weeks off, I can get away with wearing it. Also, it smells really, really bad, like turpentine. If not for those reasons it would definitely get five stars.<br /><br />Incidentally, the other top coat I use when taking a Seche Vite vacation is Revlon. It's the only other one out there that can give this product a run for its money--polish lasts just as long (about 10 days), it smells less toxic, but it takes much longer to dry.
  2252. This is by far the best top coat I've ever used! It is super shiny and it dries super fast! Highly recommended!
  2253. best I've had. with washing dishes by hand & giving kids baths, my opi & this top coat lasted 1.5 weeks before I had to really repaint. amazing
  2254. Basic top coat. No better than anything else.
  2255. The best top coat! Dries on so fast, I will often paint my nails just before bed with no smudges in the morning!

  2277. This top coat, named \\"Dry fast\\" in French, does what it says it will. Polish is dry to the touch in about 30-60 seconds and cured in about 5-10 minutes, depending on number and thickness of coats. This, I love.<br /><br />HOWEVER, a common complaint about this product is shrinkage. So common, in fact, it's been dubbed \\"seche shrinkage.\\" This is exactly what it sounds like. Somehow, when the top coat dries, it shrinks in, pulling the polish with it. Even when tips have been wrapped, this stuff unwraps them in a matter of hours. As a result, tip wear occurs within about half a day, chips occur within less than 24 hours, and polish pulls up from the edges.<br /><br />This product also contains toluene, which is no longer included in so-called \\"3-Free\\" products because of potential health hazards.<br /><br />This product dries and hardens manicures quickly, which is why I gave it two stars, but I will keep looking for a quick dry top coat that protects instead of contributes to the ruin of my manicure.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Drys/sets polish very quickly<br />Amazingly shiny<br /><br />Cons:<br />Contains toluene<br />Smells really bad<br />\\"Seche shrinkage\\"<br />Contributes to polish chipping in less than 24 hours
  2278. You can't beat this top coat. Makes an at home nail polish look like an expensive manicure. So great!

  2281. I honestly think this is the best top coat ever. It dries so quickly, and dries the layers underneath. I *hate* waiting for my nails to dry, and this cuts the dry time down immensely. Within minutes I can do something without worrying about bumping and ruining my manicure.<br /><br />The only problem I had with it was the extreme shrinkage it caused. Having a huge gap at the tips of my nails was a very unattractive look. I remedied this by wrapping my tips with the Seche Vite BEFORE applying it to the rest of the nail. I also let the tips dry just to make sure. Problem solved.
